Russia's Uralkali Group, the world's largest fertilizer producer, set potash stocks reeling Tuesday by pulling out of a cartel and vowing to ramp up production, a move that threatens to crash the $20 billion-a-year market.

The top six fertilizer makers control about 80% of potash production in two consortiums, analysts estimate. Uralkali, Plymouth, Minn.-based Mosaic (MOS), Canada's Agrium (AGU) and Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) have played off each other to stabilize prices for potash, one of the most commonly used ingredients for fertilizers.
Mosaic shares, which had been sinking in recent months, fell 18% Tuesday. Agrium lost 5%, Potash 16.5% and Intrepid Potash (IPI) 29%.
Stirring The Potash
Uralkali said it's ending its joint venture with Belarusian Potash Co.

Uralkali and Belarusian parent Belaruskali set up the BPC venture in 2005 to boost their market position. The Russian fertilizer giant blamed the Belarus government's decision to cancel BPC's exclusive right to export the country's potash.
Uralkali says it expects to boost its potash output to 13 million tons in 2014 from 10.5 million this year. Prices should fall significantly, CEO Vladislav Baumgertner said.
That's bad news for rival fertilizer makers, who will likely see sales and earnings fall.
It's seen as good news for farmers, who will pay lower prices for fertilizer if Belarus doesn't take action to woo Uralkali back into a partnership.

Shawn Hackett, author of the Hackett Money Flow Commodity Report, says the short-term boost could be a long-term drag for farmers. Lower fertilizer costs could encourage more plantings and boost harvest, hitting already-falling crop prices.
"Although fertilizer cost would fall, that's just one component," Hackett told IBD. "Insecticide, seeds and land rental costs won't fall much, if at all."
As a result, he said, "every farmer could have substantially lower revenue next year."
Hackett said Belarus may try to lure Uralkali back to the negotiating table: "Whenever you have governments and money, no one wants to see the pie shrink too much. Everyone wants to make money."
Anna Kolonchina, a Uralkali director, says in a statement on Uralkali's website that the board fully backs the decision.
"We view the fundamentals of the potash industry as strong and have confidence in the growth potential of this market," she said.
Meanwhile, CF Industries (CF), with less potash exposure than many peers, fell 2.5%. Swiss-based Syngenta (SYT) edged lower.

Stocks held near their session highs late Monday and were on pace for a second straight gain in lower volume.
The Nasdaq was up 1.1% and just a hair off the 3000 level. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 was up 0.6% and near its own milestone of 1400. The Dow Jones industrial average also climbed 0.6%.
Volume was tracking vastly lower across the board.

Zillow (Z)ramped up 5% and climbed further north of its 50-day line regained Friday. The real estate information provider will unveil Q2 results after Tuesday's close. Earnings are expected to fall 43% to 4 cents a share. But sales are slated to surge 71% to $27.1 million. The stock is in a cup-with-handle base with a 44.10 buy point. Its handle corrected 19%. A handle should typically correct 8% to 12%.

IXIA (XXIA) shaved an earlier 6% gain to 4%. The stock is still trading within the range of its July 27 surge. IXIA bolted 15% that day and cleared a 14.98 cup buy point in reaction to Q2 earnings that jumped 125% and topped views. The provider of testing and monitoring equipment also gave a strong Q3 sales outlook that day.

Apple (AAPL) stretched its gain to 1.5%. That puts it almost 1% past a 619.97 buy point from a cup-with-handle base cleared earlier Monday. On the downside, volume was tracking below average. It was pointing higher earlier in the day. Turnover should be at least 40% above average on a breakout.

CF Industries (CF) was fractionally lower ahead of its Q2 results after the close. Analysts see profit rising 30% to $8.90 a share, but that would mark a sharp slowdown from three quarters ago. Sales are slated to rise 8% to $1.95 billion. Stocks on Tuesday bounced back a bit from Monday's beating, despite a jump in Spanish bond yields and mixed U.S. economic data.
The Nasdaq rose 0.6% and the S&P 500 climbed 0.5%. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.3%. Volume ended higher on both exchanges, according to preliminary figures.

The latest reading on consumer confidence was lower than expected. But the Case-Shiller Housing Market index came in better than forecast. Meanwhile, Spain's short-term borrowing costs almost tripled at an auction Tuesday ahead of a two-day European Union summit starting Thursday.

Fertilizer maker CF Industries (CF), an IBD 50 stock, gained 3% after rising 3% and 1.5% in the prior two sessions. CF was one of several fertilizer stocks upgraded Monday by brokerage Dahlman Rose. The stock is climbing the right side of a base.
Seagate Technology (STX) rallied 4% in fast trade on news that it was being added to the S&P 500.

Coinstar (CSTR) bounced back to end a touch higher in heavy trade. The operator of Redbox DVD rental kiosks said its 2012 earnings will suffer because of its purchase of NCR Corp.'s (NCR) Blockbuster video kiosks. Coinstar assumed certain liabilities as part of the $100 million purchase.

Leading stocks were active early Thursday as a bullish crop report boosted agriculture issues.The NYSE composite and S&P 500 climbed 0.7% each. The Nasdaq struggled ahead 0.3%, weighed down by Vertex Pharmaceuticals' (VRTX) 12% slide. Volume was 7% lower on the NYSE and down 18% on the Nasdaq.The Agriculture Department projected tight U.S. feed grain supplies and reduced corn acreage for 2011-12. The report reduced the area for intended corn plantings by 1.5 million acres, primarily due to weather-related planting delays. The department also reduced its forecast for harvested area by 1.9 million acres, to 83.2 million. It projected production of 13.2 billion bushels, 305 million below last month's estimate.The news sent fertilizer makers higher. CF Industries Holdings (CF) shoveled up a 4% advance in heavy trade. The IBD 50 stock cleared a cup-with-handle base May 23.Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT), Agrium (AGU) and Mosaic (MOS) climbed 3% each.In other stocks, accessories retail/wholesaler Fossil (FOSL) pared early gains, but held a 2% advance in strong trade. The IBD 50 stock is in the fourth week of a possible square-box base, or could be rebounding off its 10-week moving average. Its relative strength and accumulation performance is still top notch.On the downside, Polypore International (PPO) crumbled 5% in heavy selling. The maker of filters used in industrial, pharmaceutical and research settings had pulled back in quiet volume the past three weeks to test support at its 10-week moving average. Thursday's move cut that line in heavy volume, sending the stock back below its 60.60 buy point from an April breakout.

Sometimes, it pays to put all or most of your eggs in one basket.
CF Industries (CF), a fertilizer producer with more than 80% of its sales coming from nitrogen-based fertilizers, has benefited from low input costs and a favorable corn planting season.

The company also sells phosphate fertilizers, such as urea, ammonia and urea ammonium nitrate. It is the second largest nitrogen fertilizer producer globally and the third largest phosphate fertilizer producer among public companies.
Michael Cox, a senior analyst at PiperJaffray, expects 2012 to be an outstanding year.

"The tightness of supply for nitrogen-based fertilizer, near-record corn planting and early spring weather season is coming together to produce record applications of nitrogen and has led to a sharp rise in demand for nitrogen fertilizer products," he said. "And CF, being the largest North American producer, is in a great position to capitalize on those trends."
Natural Gas Costs

"The other factor at play here is that natural gas costs have turned sharply lower," he added. Increases in natural gas supply and high inventory levels have been major contributors to the lower cost. As a result, CF's "primary cost-of-goods-sold line item is hitting 10-year lows."
Eighty percent of CF's cost of goods sold comes from natural gas. Declining prices have given U.S. and Canadian producers of nitrogen fertilizers a structural cost advantage vs. foreign producers.

The company reported significantly better-than-expected first-quarter results in May. Earnings per share grew 59% to $6.06, while sales jumped 30% to $1.5 billion. CF also expanded its gross margin to 47% of sales vs. 45% a year ago.

"Investors are concerned that it's as good as it gets," Cox said. "We are of the opinion that the earnings are going to prove to be much more sustainable, in part, because we think we will see another strong year for corn plantings for 2013, that new facilities are unlikely to come online to disrupt the supply-and-demand balance in the industry, and the company will be able to better capitalize on that lower natural gas cost in 2013 because they locked in higher natural gas cost for 2012."

CF's strong position is also underpinned by the buildout of production facilities that the company undertook over the course of 30 years since the 1960s. It operates seven nitrogen production facilities, of which it owns five. Those facilities are served by five natural gas pipelines in North America and on-site storage capacity.
The facilities are also conveniently located near major farm areas with easy access to corn growers.
In addition to the North American operations, CF holds ownership in several joint ventures, including those in the U.K. and in Trinidad.

Its phosphate operations include 3.5 million tons of phosphate mining capacity. The business is vertically integrated, which provides CF with full self-sufficiency in the phosphate rock supply and reserves spanning at least 10 years, writes Tim Tiberio, an analyst at Miller Tabak & Co., in a company report.

"Their international exposure is in their phosphate nutrient category and I think that the opportunity there is significant," said Cox. "A big part of that is selling into Latin America. ... As acreage shifts towards corn and soybeans, that will create incremental demand for fertilizer nutrients."

But the primary business is still domestic nitrogen fertilizers. In 2010, it acquired a 75% interest in Terra Nitrogen, expanding its nitrogen capacity by 124% and providing access to its manufacturing facility in Verdigris, Okla.

"They've established a network of ammonia facilities, which is the base building block of nitrogen fertilizer and storage terminals," said Cox. "Having this network is a key competitive advantage, which I don't think that investors generally give the company credit for.
"Getting a new terminal in place is a very long process, if it can be done at all."
Its main competitors are Yara International and the much smaller Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF).
Shopping For Buyouts

Another growth opportunity would be acquisitions, said Cox. "They are continually evaluating to bolster their production capacity . .. . That would be smaller players that have a strategic location of their facilities that serve various markets better."
Speedy delivery to the customer is key as it proved to be this spring with low inventory levels at the farm and retail-level centers.
Finally, CF bought back $1 billion in shares in the second half of last year and plans to buy back more in 2012. It has $500 million remaining on the program.
The company expects tight grain stocks and high projected crop prices for 2012.

The forecast for U.S. corn planting is 93.5 million acres, which will create near-record levels of nitrogen demand, CF states in its first-quarter earnings report. In addition, lower and less volatile raw material costs should continue into the future.Sometimes, it pays to put all or most of your eggs in one basket.CF Industries (CF), a fertilizer producer with more than 80% of its sales coming from nitrogen-based fertilizers, has benefited from low input costs and a favorable corn planting season.The company also sells phosphate fertilizers, such as urea, ammonia and urea ammonium nitrate. When the dust settled or should I say when the fertilizer settled on Tuesday's earnings reaction for agricultural chemicals producer CF Industries  (CF), shares managed to gain about 1.3% despite mixed results. Technically, CF remains situated within a six-week high handle or flat base pattern formed around its prior all-time highs set back in early May.

On spot not so fortunate to rally around the results were CF Industries Weeklys options. Bulls and bears buying premium in front of the event unsurprisingly take a dip from last night's close as uncertainty surrounding the event was removed. The bad news for bearish buyers of puts, the triple whammy of being wrong on their delta bias, time decay and implieds getting mowed down by about 40% took their toll on those contracts life.

Case in point, last night's slightly out-of-the-money AugWk2 200 put fetched $3.65 on 61% IV with shares near 203.50. By Tuesday's close and CF near 206, the contract is priced for about $0.95 with implieds off about 20 points at 42%. The 205 put with its larger delta fared even worse with a mid-market price of $2.50 which compares to yesterday's close of $6.00.

At the same time, call buyers also ended up on the short end of the stick. The in-the-money 195 call which maintained about two points of extrinsic value and net market price of $10.40 on Tuesday was the first deeper strike to show any profitability, but only a puny $0.40 per contract to finish at $10.80 despite the gain in shares and its mid-70s delta. From there and looking at the near, at and out-of-money calls, bulls took a systematic hit with strikes from 200 and higher all showing losses. Ultimately, Tuesday's relatively small move wasn't enough to prevent time decay and lower implieds from eating away at the price of those contracts.

It becomes quite obvious the big winner(s) are those traders which took the other side of being long puts, calls, straddles, strangles and the likes. In fact, even a miscued stock hedge or two during the day in order to keep the delta count flat, while reducing profitability should have been more a nuisance than menace. Of course, some verticals also made money depending on their positioning relative to shares. In-the-money spreads had the opportunity to expand towards max profitability and an at-the-money such as the 200 / 205 bull call spread benefited from its delta, time decay and vega allowance.

Less obvious maybe and maybe to sow a fresh idea for option traders down the road, is the long time or calendar spread. Last night's decent volatility skew between contract months and fairly low implieds statistically allowed buyers of time spreads to capture profits as well. For instance, the Sept / AugWk2 205 call spread went from about $5.40 and an implied skew of nearly 25 points with the front sold contract near 60% IV and the long back month call around 35% IV, to $6.50 and virtually no skew with implieds in the low 30s for both. Now there's some food for thought that's worth fertilizing.

What do you think? Stocks opened to mild losses in weak trade Wednesday.

The Nasdaq was a fraction lower and the S&P 500 slipped 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 0.2%. Volume was down 2% on the Nasdaq and 5% lower on the NYSE compared with the same time Tuesday.
The stock market today opened to mixed economic news, with a surprise jump in April's Producer Price Index pointing to rekindled inflation.

Earnings news continued to drive much of Wednesday's early stock action. Cosmetics brand Coty (COTY) climbed 5%, while apparel and accessories maker Kate Spade (KATE) bagged a 6% gain after reporting quarterly results.

Deere & Co. (DE) slipped more than 1%. The farm and construction equipment maker beat the consensus sales and earnings forecasts for its fiscal second quarter, but management lowered the company's full-year sales outlook.
The stock broke out of a long pattern April 1 and is slightly above the 91.68 buy point.

Sears Holdings (SHLD) climbed 4% at the starting gun. The Illinois-based retail chain said it might sell all or part of its Sears Canada subsidiary, the latest in a series of divestments that included Land's End, Orchard Supply Hardware and Sears Hometown & Outlet Stores. Sears owns 51% of Sears Canada, which had 449 stores and reported a profit of $364 million in 2013.
Leaders got off to another weak start, with almost 80% of the IBD 50 stocks opening lower.

But drugmakers Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) and Salix Pharmaceuticals (SLXP) jumped more than 2% each. Jazz is climbing off a test of support at its 40-week moving average, but is still below its 10-week line as it consolidates. Stocks do constructive things during a correction.
If you are mostly in cash, you can relax and wait for new bases and base-on-base patterns to develop.

Yet, this correction isn't without its problems. On many charts, the leaders are beginning to look like doughnuts near closing time — they've been around too long. The bases are late stage, and the late-stage base is more prone to failure.
CF Industries Holdings (CF) and Howard Hughes Corp. (HHC) are working on second-stage patterns.
They also are showing action that is understandable during market corrections — high handles.

For example, Howard Hughes recently broke out of a second-stage base. We discussed some drawbacks in this stock's fundamentals in the May 31 IBD, but we revisit it now to make a point about chart action during market corrections.

Howard Hughes cleared an imperfect handle at 70.24 (visible only on the daily chart) on May 25 in 32% faster trade. A breakout needs at least 40% greater volume to be considered valid. Given that Hughes is thinly traded, the volume looked especially inadequate.

The left-side high posed a second potential buy point at 73.89, but volume was below average when Hughes cleared it on May 27. Big volume kicked in May 31 as the November 2010 initial public offering posted an all-time high.
The high became the peak of a high handle, setting up another potential buy point.
A market correction creates head winds that can shape high handles.
Fertilizer maker CF Industries cleared a 144.09 buy point in a second-stage cup with handle on May 23. Volume was 95% above average. The stock advanced 10% past the buy point and then declined.
The decline has shaped a high handle.

Should the market return to an uptrend, stay alert for breakouts from high handles.Stocks do constructive things during a correction.If you are mostly in cash, you can relax and wait for new bases and base-on-base patterns to develop.Yet, this correction isn't without its problems. High crop prices have farmers flush with cash and are delivering a cornucopia of sales for seed companies, grains processors and fertilizer makers.

That's keeping expectations high for CF Industries (CF), a nitrogen fertilizer maker, which reports Thursday after the close. Analysts expect earnings excluding special one-time items to rise 26% to $4.81 per share. Revenue is seen climbing 7.2% to $1.26 billion.
Shares lifted 1% to 197.32.

On Tuesday nitrogen fertilizer maker CVR Partners (UAN) posted lower-than-expected sales, in part due to unscheduled down-time for plant maintenance in March. But that was offset by the higher prices. It upped its full-year guidance in the face of those higher prices and the increased capacity it expects in the wake of that maintenance work.
The company's shares slipped early but had mostly recovered and traded at 28.99 midday.
U.S. farmers this spring are planting what the government projects to be the largest corn crop in 75 years.

On Tuesday, grains processor and marketer Archer Daniels Midland (ADM) posted better-than-expected fiscal third-quarter results, excluding restructuring and other one-time expenses, and was upbeat on projected large U.S. corn and soybean crops.
Food ingredients maker Corn Products International (CPO) also topped analyst forecasts Tuesday.
Farm equipment maker Agco (AGCO) on Tuesday also beat on rising sales, mirroring larger rival CNH Global (CNH), which beat views last week.

The largest agriculture equipment maker, Deere (DE), is due to report fiscal Q2 on May 16.High crop prices have farmers flush with cash and are delivering a cornucopia of sales for seed companies, grains processors and fertilizer makers.That's keeping expectations high for CF Industries (CF), a nitrogen fertilizer maker, which reports Thursday after the close. U.S. farmers are set to plant their largest corn crop since World War II, lured in by high prices for the commodity and tight supplies.
The report from the U.S. Department of Agriculture on Monday sent agriculture and grain stocks higher, including Archer Daniels Midland (ADM), Monsanto (MON) and Bunge (BG).
Shares of fertilizer makers CF Industries (CF) and Agrium (AGU) were also up in intraday trading.
Farm equipment companies Deere (DE) and Tractor Supply Co. (TSCO) also were trading higher.
The report forecasts 94 million acres of corn to be planted this spring, up from 91.92 million acres planted in 2011. That would be the largest crop since the 95.48 million acres planted in 1944.
Corn stocks are expected to end next summer at 1.6 billion bushels, almost twice this year's supply, which are the lowest in 16 years.
That rising supply should ease prices for restaurants and food manufacturers, who are facing sharply higher commodity costs, and for consumers who grapple with higher grocery bills.

The government expects corn prices to average $5 per bushel in the 2012-13 marketing year, down from the current $6.70. It expects that price to continue lower to $4.30 the following year, before starting to climb again.
Last week, grains and oilseed processor Bunge and ingredients maker Corn Products International (CPO) forecast rising crop demand in 2012, as both posted higher-than-expected fourth-quarter results.
USDA's latest report projects the amount of corn for feed at 5.225 billion bushels, up from 4.6 billion this year. Corn for ethanol is seen slipping to 4.950 billion from 5.0 billion this year.

Exports are expected to climb to 1.875 billion bushels from 1.7 billion this year. The U.S. is the world's largest corn exporter. Demand is expected to rise in China as growing wealth fuels appetites for meat, requiring more feed.

Fertilizer may sound like an unromantic business, but in the last two years the industry has been a real soap opera. CF Industries (CF) played a leading role. In early 2009, as the recession pummeled agriculture, it got a $3.6 billion merger proposal from Canadian giant Agrium (AGU). But CF only had eyes for Terra Industries, which was inconveniently already…
Stock futures ladled out moderate losses ahead of Friday's open, as an uptick in May producer prices added to the inflation pressure on the Federal Reserve.
Dow futures slipped 39.4 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures dropped 15.3 points and S&P 500 futures were down 5.4 points.

The stock market today heads into Friday with the Nasdaq up 0.3% this week and the S&P 500 ahead 0.8%. The Nasdaq continued to find support at its 50-day moving average. The S&P 500 slipped below that level late last week, but retook support on Wednesday. A significant change in the eurozone's debt standoff with Greece, or clarity regarding a possible rate increase by the Federal Reserve, could help urge indexes out of their months-long limits. But until the market challenges the high or lows of its recent range, investors must stay prepared for a shift in either direction.

In economic news, prices paid to producers rose 0.5% in May, the Labor Department reported, the largest increase since at least December. The gain reversed April's 0.4% decline, and it topped analyst expectations for a 0.4% increase. The core Producer Price Index, minus energy and food, edged up 0.1% vs. a 0.2% slip in April and in line with expectations.
The University of Michigan is slated to release its initial June consumer sentiment estimate at 10 a.m. ET.

Stock action showedTwitter (TWTR) perking up 3% after announcing Chief Executive Dick Costolo will step down July 1. Twitter co-founder and Chairman Jack Dorsey will serve as interim CEO during a search for a new CEO. Dorsey said he would take no compensation for the position until later in the year. The stock has been unable to exit a consolidation begun shortly after its November 2013 IPO. It ended Thursday 52% below its Dec. 27 high.

Connecticut-based biotech Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN) dropped more than 2% in premarket action. The stock has been in a deepening consolidation since December and has been struggling to regain its 10-week moving average since early May.

Among IBD 50 stocks, Synaptics (SYNA) rose 2% before the open. The company announced Thursday it had reached a milestone, with shipments of fingerprint sensors now topping 200 million units. The sensors are used in smartphones, tablets and notebook computers. The stock has been hovering just below a June 3 high, ending Thursday almost 7% above a 91.33 buy point.

Overseas, markets across Asia ended higher, led by a 1.4% jump by Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index. The Shanghai Composite rose 0.9% to end the week up 2.8%. The Hang Seng ended up a fraction for the week. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 rose 0.1% Friday to end the week effectively flat.
Europe's top indexes were also tracking toward flat finishes for the week, with the FTSE 100 in London, Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC-40 in Paris all showing moderate losses near midday.

The dollar continued to gain ground, keeping downward pressure on stocks and commodity prices. Oil and gold traded lower, with West Texas Intermediate futures holding just above $60 per barrel and the August gold contract trading at $1,179.20 an ounce. For the week, oil was up not quite 2%. Handling A Choppy Uptrend: Seventh and Last In A Series
Bigger isn't always better if you're an individual investor trying to weather a choppy market.
In other words, it's not true that all large-capitalization stocks handle volatile periods better than midcaps or small caps.
Big caps often can serve as a safe port in a storm, but in some cases you'll still feel plenty of waves.
With this final installment in our Investor's Corner series on handling a choppy uptrend, we're pointing out some highly rated big caps that are actually somewhat volatile.
Just keep these examples in mind as you deal with the current market, which has been advancing in a herky-jerky fashion.
For starters, don't forget that a big cap is generally a stock with a market capitalization of at least $10 billion or $15 billion.

We're talking about some big names like Cisco Systems (CSCO) ($92 billion market cap) or Kraft Foods (KFT) ($73 billion), not smaller players like Chiquita (CQB) ($264 million) or Zynga (ZNGA) ($1 billion).
Remember also that some big caps still are managing to show strong gains in earnings and revenue — increases of 25% or more — even though they're building off a sizable base.

That helps explain the potential for volatility. Sure, these are often well-established companies, but they still can struggle to meet Wall Street's expectations. And that can lead to dives in price that you might not generally associate with such huge players.
One way to tell if the big cap you're eyeing is on the volatile side is to check out its beta, a metric that gauges a stock's sensitivity to the general market's movement in either direction.
For example, a beta of 1.50 would mean that in the past year, the stock moved 50% more than the S&P 500, either up or down.
One example of a volatile big cap would be Seagate Technology (STX), the data storage giant. As shown in the nearby table, Seagate has a beta of 1.56.

That means it moved 56% more than the S&P 500 in the last year. Seagate's beta is hardly a surprise when you consider the company operates in a highly competitive and cyclical business. Another data company in the table, Teradata (TDC), has a similar beta.

CF Industries (CF) also appears in the nearby table because of its significant beta. Again, it's not a surprise because fertilizer makers such as CF can be buffeted by the latest crop reports, drought fears, other weather news and other factors.

If you're looking for stability, there are of course some highly rated big caps with low betas. Hershey (HSY), Wal-Mart (WMT) and Dollar General (DG) all fit the bill. Each has a beta below 0.5, meaning it has been gyrating half as much as the general market.Handling A Choppy Uptrend: Seventh and Last In A SeriesBigger isn't always better if you're an individual investor trying to weather a choppy market.In other words, it's not true that all large-capitalization stocks handle volatile periods better than midcaps or small caps.Big caps often can serve as a safe port in a storm, but in some cases you'll still feel plenty of waves.With this final installment in our Investor's Corner series on handling a choppy uptrend, we're pointing out some highly rated big caps that are actually somewhat volatile.Just keep these examples in mind as you deal with the current market, which has been advancing in a herky-jerky fashion.For starters, don't forget that a big cap is generally a stock with a market capitalization of at least $10 billion or $15 billion.We're talking about some big names like Cisco Systems (CSCO) ($92 billion market cap) or Kraft Foods (KFT) ($73 billion), not smaller players like Chiquita (CQB) ($264 million) or Zynga (ZNGA) ($1 billion).Remember also that some big caps still are managing to show strong gains in earnings and revenue — increases of 25% or more — even though they're building off a sizable base.That helps explain the potential for volatility. Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF), a maker of nitrogen-based fertilizers, is just below a new high after clearing an 11-week base.The stock, which went public at 20 a share in November, is just 3% off its July 17 peak of 31.34. It's been choppy lately, in line with the market's volatility.The base is a second-stage pattern, increasing its chance of success over those in later stages.The Chemicals-Agricultural industry group has climbed in recent weeks as the Midwest drought has raised prices of corn and other crops. The industry was ranked No. 46 in Friday's IBD, up from 93 three weeks ago.Los Angeles-based Rentech has the highest Composite Rating in the group, a best-possible 99. That's better than rivals  Agrium (AGU) and CF Industries (CF), which are IBD 50 stocks.Rentech is expected to report on Aug. 10 that Q2 profit soared 218% from the same period last year, which would mark the third triple-digit profit increase in the past five quarters.Meanwhile, sales growth has picked up for two straight quarters, from a 10% increase in Q3 2011 to subsequent gains of 47% and 61%. After-tax margin has risen in a range of 8.6% to 50.3% over the past three quarters.Rentech shares have climbed for eight of the past nine weeks — including three up weeks in strong volume — as the stock formed the right side of its base. The bottom of the base was marked by an upside weekly reversal, a bullish sign.The stock trades fewer than 400,000 shares a day, which tends to discourage institutional investors.However, Rentech's Accumulation-Distribution Rating has risen to B from C+ in the past week, and its up-down volume ratio is 1.5, continuing a positive trend the past few weeks.

Stocks closed off their best levels of the day, but still logged a second straight gain Monday. The Nasdaq rallied 0.7% while the NYSE composite rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 0.2%. All three were up 0.6% to 1.1% at session peaks, respectively. Volume fell sharply on both major exchanges, marking the second straight day of gains in lower trade.…
Stocks turned negative at midday Thursday as jitters about Washington's budget impasse weighed on investors despite improved jobs data.

The S&P 500 was down 0.3% after starting out fractionally higher. The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average were each down 0.2%. Volume was mixed, up 16% on the Nasdaq and 2% lower on the NYSE compared with the same time Wednesday.

Best Buy (BBY) soared almost 19% following a report that founder Richard Schulze will pay between $5 billion and $6 billion to buy the consumer electronics retailer by Sunday. The brick-and-mortar chain's sales have suffered as consumers increasingly turn to online competitors.

Meanwhile, IBD 50 stock Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU), a challenger to Baidu's (BIDU)lead in the Chinese search-engine market, was up 1% in above-average volume. The stock is in buying range, roughly 2% above a 24.40 entry. But the stock's pullback following a negative reversal last week is a caution sign.

CF Industries (CF) and Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF) continued to fall a day after Goldman Sachs said it sees more risk in the producers of nitrogen fertilizers due to weather-related delays to planting.
CF sank more than 1%, dipping below its 50-day line, in modest volume. The stock has pulled back below a 215.10 handle buy point after clearing the mark in light volume.
Rentech, meanwhile, lost almost 2%, getting support at its 50-day line. The stock is forming a handle after falling below a 40.15 flat-base entry.

In economic news, new claims for jobless benefits sank by a greater-than-expected 32,000 last week to 343,000, suggesting improvement in the labor market. Also, retail sales edged up 0.3% in November, reversing the previous month's 0.3% decline. But the gain was slightly less than expected and sales excluding autos were flat.

Meanwhile, there was little sign of progress in talks to prevent a combination of tax hikes and spending cuts due to take effect Jan. 1. Sales growth is an important gauge. But growing sales don't tell you whether a company is truly a top-shelf or bottom-rung player. And it doesn't tell you if a company might be slashing prices to move its inventory.Profit margins can add several important dimensions to your research.Sales provide capital to fuel a company's operations. Profits reveal how effectively the company achieves those sales. They also show how much muscle an outfit builds to reinvest in operations, to develop and market new products, and to offer employees incentives to innovate and excel.To gauge a company's profits, take a look at pretax margins.Pretax margins can be sliced and diced a number of ways, but aim to show earnings, before taxes, as a percentage of overall revenue. (EBITDA, or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, is a similar measure, showing a company's profitability minus the effects of accounting and financing strategies.)Margins can vary widely from industry to industry. But the ratio provides a good gauge of peer strength in any particular industry group.Among fertilizer makers, for example, CF Industries (CF) generated a 45% pretax margin last year. That is well above Mosaic's (MOS) 26% margin and the 13% margin for Agrium (AGU). But it lagged Terra Nitrogen (TNH), a master limited partnership which sports a 64% pretax ratio.Part of that difference is due to the companies' differing focus on nitrogen-based fertilizers. Nitrogen products have commanded somewhat higher prices this year, while the basic raw material, natural gas, has been unusually cheap.Agrium is more diversified, with just over a third of its pretax earnings coming from nitrogen last year. Nitrogen was more than 90% of CF Industries' pretax take. Mosaic, on the other hand, is focused on phosphate and potassium-based fertilizers.After-tax margins help dig a little deeper. In IBD's market columns, writers frequently point out a company's margin changes on a year-over-year basis.CF's after-tax margin was 26.4% in the first quarter. That was only slightly below the fourth-quarter peak of 27.3%. Measured on a year-over-year basis, CF has increased its after-tax margins in four consecutive quarters.Agrium has increased after-tax margins in eight straight quarters. Its Q1 after tax margin was 5.7%, down sharply from 11.9% in Q4 and well below the 21.6% high notched in Q4 2008. Again, CF is on better footing.IBD's combined Sales Growth, Profit Margins and Return on Equity grade, called the SMR Rating, also incorporates margin strength. CF Industries, Agrium and Terra Nitrogen carry SMR Ratings of A. Mosaic's SMR Rating is a B.
The world's largest seed company, Monsanto (MON), reported stronger-than-expected third-quarter results as farmers rushed to plant more corn and other crops to capture high commodity prices.
The developer of genetically engineered corn, soybeans and other crops said its specialized seeds — including some newly introduced varieties — were strong, as were sales of herbicides.
Shares climbed 3.9% to 80.90 by early afternoon trading.
The St. Louis, Mo., company reported earnings of $1.63 per share, excluding one-time items, up 27% from a year ago. Analysts were expecting $1.60 per share.
Net revenue climbed 17% to $4.2 billion, above analyst consensus estimates of $4 billion.
It reaffirmed full-year adjusted guidance of $3.65 to $3.70 EPS. Analysts forecast $3.70.

"We've achieved excellent business results this year, but more importantly we've continued to receive positive response to our products from farmers," CEO Hugh Grant said in a statement. "As I look to 2013 and beyond, I am confident as our momentum is now validated with sustained business results and I believe the opportunity ahead for our customers, our business and our owners is significant."
Corn seed — including those with genetic traits designed to thrive in adverse conditions — climbed 35%, the company said. Soybean sales were up 15%.
Farmers in the U.S. planted 96 million acres of corn earlier this year, according to government data, the largest in 75 years.

The next installment of the government's closely watched World Agricultural Supply and Demand Estimates, or WASDE, is due out July 11. Despite the huge planting, some analysts think that report will show effects of unfavorable weather in parts of the country, reducing harvest forecasts.
That could be a boon for fertilizer makers, and farmers try to preserve their yields.
Grains and oilseeds processor Bunge (BG) climbed 1.3% in early afternoon trading.

Stocks were hitting session highs late Thursday, recouping a big chunk of the previous day's losses, amid mixed earnings reports and economic data.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.7%, the Nasdaq rallied 0.6% and the S&P 500 added 0.3%. Volume was tracking higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the NYSE compared to the same time Wednesday.

In the stock market today, NQ Mobile (NQ) plunged as much as 55% in massive volume after short seller Muddy Waters Research Group slapped a "strong sell" rating on the stock, calling the Chinese developer of mobile security software a "massive fraud."
Muddy Waters accused the company of falsifying financial information and vastly overstating its market share in China.
Meanwhile, gunmaker Sturm Ruger (RGR) dropped 5% in volume that was running more than double its daily average.
The stock had recently risen 20% above a 56.98 buy point, a level at which investors should consider taking profits. It's now 13% above the buy point.

Generac Holdings (GNRC) was the biggest gainer among IBD 50 stocks. The maker of portable generators gapped up and bolted 15% after reporting Q3 results that blew away views. The company also raised its full-year sales outlook due to strong demand for its residential generators and impact from its Baldor Generators buyout. Generac cleared a 44.34 buy point from a late-stage double-bottom base.

Elsewhere, Medidata Solutions (MDSO) soared 16% to a new high after the provider of clinical development software reported that Q3 profit jumped 67% from a year earlier, beating Wall Street expectations. Sales for the period rose 27%.

Stocks opened lower, but bounced back and were narrowly mixed early Wednesday. The S&P 500 edged up 0.2%, while the Nasdaq was fractionally higher. But the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.1%. Volume was tracking higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq compared with the same time Tuesday. Fertilizer stocks gained after the Department of Agriculture trimmed its…
Wall Street was up slightly in weak trade early Friday afternoon, led by gains in agriculture and health care stocks, amid mixed economic data.

The Dow Jones industrials chugged 0.5% higher. The S&P 500 crept ahead 0.4%, while the Nasdaq was flat after being down mildly amid a second straight decline for Apple (AAPL). Volume was little changed on the Nasdaq and down 9% on the NYSE vs. the same time Thursday.

Fertilizer maker CF Industries (CF) was up 2%, finding support at its 10-week line. Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF), another agricultural chemicals firm, was also up 2%. The stock has risen 40% since going public last November.
Also, Terra Nitrogen (TNH), another fertilizer maker, rose nearly 1% after earlier hitting a new high. The stock has been consolidating for three weeks.
In a Friday report, the Agriculture Department noted lower-than-expected stockpiles of wheat and corn and an outlook for reduced planting for soybeans.

Meanwhile, managed health care provider Humana (HUM) was up more than 1% in above-average volume. Health care stocks have risen for the past couple days as the Supreme Court mulls whether to scrap the Obama administration's medical overhaul.
Centene (CNC), another managed health care provider, popped 4% and is just below a 50.46 potential buy point in the sixth week of a cup-shaped base.

Elsewhere, new issue Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) was up 3%, climbing toward its March 26 high that followed a strong rebound from support at its 10-week moving average. The IBD 50 stock is 40% past an IPO base buy point of 22.91 and 114% above its October initial offering price.

In economic news, the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index unexpectedly rose in March, climbing for the fourth month in five, amid improving job growth. Consumer spending rose more than expected in February, according to the Commerce Department.
But Midwest business activity was less positive. The Chicago Purchasing Managers Index fell 1.8 points in March to 62.2, short of forecasts of 63. It was the gauge's third decline in four months.

On the downside, InvenSense (INVN), a maker of motion-sensing chips for video game machines and other consumer electronic devices, was the biggest loser among IBD 50 stocks. It sank 8% to its 10-week moving average in huge volume.

A bounce off the key support level in strong volume would normally give owners of the stock a chance to add to their positions, but two big high-volume declines this week are a worry. The maker of motion-sensing chips for consumer electronic devices has been volatile since going public late last year.

Tibco Software (TIBX), a leader in database integration, reversed lower and was down 6% after reporting late Thursday its Q1 EPS rose 25% to 20 cents a share, a penny past analyst estimates. Revenue increased 22% to $225.7 million, above views for $222.3 million.
The IBD 50 stock gained 5% Thursday, taking new highs atop a seven-week advance. Friday's drop left it 2% above a 30.04 buy point after clearing a cup-with-handle base in light trade March 9.

Standard & Poor's raised the stock's outlook to positive from stable on Thursday and said it could raise its rating "in the next 12 months if (the company) continues its very good operating performance."
Finish Line (FINL) gapped down and crashed 14% after reporting Q4 earnings rose 25% to meet the 81 cent analyst consensus. A 19% gain in revenue, to $456.3 million, easily topped expectations.
But the company offered Q1 earnings guidance well below analyst forecasts due to strategic spending, a shift in the promotional calendar and an increase in occupancy costs.

The move sent the stock plunging below its 10-week line, driving the stock back below a 22.10 buy point in a seven-week cup base following a February breakout.Wall Street was up slightly in weak trade early Friday afternoon, led by gains in agriculture and health care stocks, amid mixed economic data.The Dow Jones industrials chugged 0.5% higher. The S&P 500 crept ahead 0.4%, while the Nasdaq was flat after being down mildly amid a second straight decline for Apple (AAPL). Volume was little changed on the Nasdaq and down 9% on the NYSE vs. the same time Thursday.Fertilizer maker CF Industries (CF) was up 2%, finding support at its 10-week line. Rentech Nitrogen Partners (RNF), another agricultural chemicals firm, was also up 2%. The stock has risen 40% since going public last November.Also, Terra Nitrogen (TNH), another fertilizer maker, rose nearly 1% after earlier hitting a new high. The stock has been consolidating for three weeks.In a Friday report, the Agriculture Department noted lower-than-expected stockpiles of wheat and corn and an outlook for reduced planting for soybeans.Meanwhile, managed health care provider Humana (HUM) was up more than 1% in above-average volume. Health care stocks have risen for the past couple days as the Supreme Court mulls whether to scrap the Obama administration's medical overhaul.Centene (CNC), another managed health care provider, popped 4% and is just below a 50.46 potential buy point in the sixth week of a cup-shaped base.Elsewhere, new issue Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT) was up 3%, climbing toward its March 26 high that followed a strong rebound from support at its 10-week moving average. The IBD 50 stock is 40% past an IPO base buy point of 22.91 and 114% above its October initial offering price.In economic news, the Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index unexpectedly rose in March, climbing for the fourth month in five, amid improving job growth. Consumer spending rose more than expected in February, according to the Commerce Department.But Midwest business activity was less positive. The Chicago Purchasing Managers Index fell 1.8 points in March to 62.2, short of forecasts of 63. It was the gauge's third decline in four months.On the downside, InvenSense (INVN), a maker of motion-sensing chips for video game machines and other consumer electronic devices, was the biggest loser among IBD 50 stocks. It sank 8% to its 10-week moving average in huge volume.A bounce off the key support level in strong volume would normally give owners of the stock a chance to add to their positions, but two big high-volume declines this week are a worry. The maker of motion-sensing chips for consumer electronic devices has been volatile since going public late last year.Tibco Software (TIBX), a leader in database integration, reversed lower and was down 6% after reporting late Thursday its Q1 EPS rose 25% to 20 cents a share, a penny past analyst estimates. Revenue increased 22% to $225.7 million, above views for $222.3 million.The IBD 50 stock gained 5% Thursday, taking new highs atop a seven-week advance. Friday's drop left it 2% above a 30.04 buy point after clearing a cup-with-handle base in light trade March 9.Standard & Poor's raised the stock's outlook to positive from stable on Thursday and said it could raise its rating "in the next 12 months if (the company) continues its very good operating performance."Finish Line (FINL) gapped down and crashed 14% after reporting Q4 earnings rose 25% to meet the 81 cent analyst consensus. A 19% gain in revenue, to $456.3 million, easily topped expectations.But the company offered Q1 earnings guidance well below analyst forecasts due to strategic spending, a shift in the promotional calendar and an increase in occupancy costs.The move sent the stock plunging below its 10-week line, driving the stock back below a 22.10 buy point in a seven-week cup base following a February breakout.

Stocks scored respectable gains Tuesday after a seesaw session, helped by an upbeat consumer confidence report and Apple's (AAPL) 2% advance. The Nasdaq rose 0.7% while the NYSE composite and the S&P 500 added 0.3%. Volume increased slightly from Monday's level on both main exchanges. The major indexes started out mixed, as two economic reports released before the open missed…

Farmers have cultivated corn for about 9,000 years, and for about 9,000 years they've cursed the weather for refusing to do what it's supposed to do. That tradition holds true this year, as frigid weather in the Midwest and cold, wet weather in the South have complicated the start of this spring's corn-growing season. Nothing can get the market past mixed economic data like a new iPad. News that Apple (AAPL) could unveil its new gadget sparked the tech sector and gave the market a leg up Tuesday. The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, the S&P 500 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.2%. The S&P 500 hit its highest since June 2008. The Dow's…

Stocks stayed in positive territory and near session highs in early-afternoon action Tuesday. The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.3% and the Dow tacked on 0.2%. Volume remained down slightly from Monday's levels on both main exchanges. Apple (AAPL) gained 2% in heavy trade, reaching another fresh high. The company sent out invitations to reporters Tuesday for…

Stocks got hammered in early trading Friday following a weak job report. The Nasdaq tumbled 1.2%. The S&P 500 dropped 0.8% and sliced its 50-day line. The Dow Jones industrial average shed 0.7%, with 28 of its 30 components lower. Volume was tracking higher across the board compared with the same time Thursday. Earlier, the Labor Department said the economy added…

Nobody likes mixed messages. Investing is easier when everything lines up in the same direction. Right now, there are a fair number of stocks with ratings that are at odds with each other. Just look at the stocks in Friday's Stock Spotlight Screen. For example, Corn Products (CPO) is in the No. 1 sector — food and drink. But its…

The general market eased Thursday after a barrage of economic data, but energy and agriculture stocks climbed on rising oil prices and a bullish crop report.The NYSE composite, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each slipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed: up slightly on the NYSE and down an equal amount on the Nasdaq compared with the same time Wednesday.Crude oil prices jumped to nearly $107 a barrel as Libyan rebel forces fled the oil-refinery town of Ras Lanuf and faced intense fighting in the oil port town of Brega. The dollar also helped lift oil, as the greenback slipped vs. the euro after a European Central Bank official suggested the bank was eyeing a "a series of rate hikes rather than just one."The U.S. Department of Agriculture's annual prospective plantings report showed increases in the number of acres planted with corn, wheat and cotton, with a decline in acres dedicated to soybeans. The increase in corn acreage, to 92.2 million, was above estimates for 91.6 million, but below the 93.4 million threshold analysts say are needed to ease supply constraints.Ongoing jobless claims decreased to 3.714 million in the week ended March 19, down from an upwardly revised 3.765 million for the prior week, according to the Labor Department.The Chicago Purchasing Manager's Index for March was 70.6, down from February but ahead of forecasts for 69.5. CF Industries Holdings (CF) popped more than 3% in massive trade following the USDA's crop report. The Illinois-based fertilizer producer has been struggling to retake support at its 10-week moving average. It is in the seventh week of a possible base. The stock holds a 90 Composite Rating from IBD.Farm equipment maker AGCO (AGCO) jumped more than 2% in early trade. The Duluth, Ga.-based tractor and combine maker is just above its 10-week moving average and six weeks into a flat base. It holds a Composite Rating of 88. Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating is a weak D.Fabless chip maker Cavium Networks  (CAVM) scorched ahead 3% after Auriga USA upgraded the stock to buy from hold. The stock is in the 11th week of a double-bottom base, with a potential 46.08 buy point.

Stocks opened narrowly mixed Thursday, hurt by worrisome bond trading in Europe and soft October U.S. manufacturing data. The Dow Jones industrial average traded fractionally higher. The Nasdaq slipped 0.4% and the S&P 500 edged 0.3% lower. Trade was 4% higher on the NYSE and up 20% on the Nasdaq compared with the same time yesterday. Stocks got an early…

Stock futures signaled a sharply higher open Friday as a better-than-expected jobs report helped calm nerves following Thursday's massive sell-off.Nasdaq 100 futures rose 16 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures rallied 12 points and Dow futures gained 100 points.In economic news, the Labor Department said the U.S. economy added 117,000 jobs in July, beating expectations for 84,000 new jobs. Job gains in May and June were revised higher by a total of 56,000. The unemployment rate eased to 9.1%. Economists expected the rate to hold steady at 9.2%.Futures turned higher following the report. Gold pared gains, while bonds dipped.Worries over a double-dip recession at home and concerns about a worsening debt crisis in several euro zone countries have weighed in recent weeks. On Thursday, stocks stumbled to their lowest levels since late last year.In corporate news, Priceline (PCLN) rose 10% in the pre-market after beating views late Thursday. The provider of online travel services logged a 78% gain in Q2 earnings, its biggest increase in 15 quarters. Sales grew 44%, the best in 12 periods. Priceline also guided Q3 results above analyst estimates.CF Industries Holdings (CF) rallied 5% in pre-open trading. Late Thursday, the the fertilizer maker posted Q2 profit of $6.87 a share, up from $2.48 the prior year and well above views for $5.95 a share. Sales climbed 38% to $1.8 billion, ending three prior quarters of triple-digit gains. CF also quadrupled its dividend and said it would buy back $1.5 billion of its own stock.First Solar (FSLR) dropped 5% ahead of the bell after badly missing views late Thursday. The solar modules maker said its Q2 earnings tumbled 62% to 70 cents a share, below expectations of 92 cents. Sales fell 9% to $532.8 million, missing estimates by more than $50 million. The company also cut its full-year sales guidance.

Wall Street held onto modest gains late Friday afternoon, led by agriculture and health care stocks. The Dow Jones industrials and S&P 500 each chugged 0.5% higher. The Nasdaq was up 0.2% after being down mildly amid a second straight decline for Apple (AAPL). Volume was down 3% on the Nasdaq and 10% on the NYSE vs. the same time…

After retaking their 50-day moving averages, the stock indexes eased but still held above the key area. The Nasdaq was up 1.2%, while the S&P 500 and the NYSE composite added 0.9% and 1.0% respectively. The Philadelphia semiconductor index was up 2.4%. Volume was down on the NYSE and up on the Nasdaq. If the indexes hold above their 50-day…
Stocks jumped in heavy trading Friday, with Apple 's (AAPL) iPhone launch and quiet progress on a eurozone bailout for Spain buoying the market.

The Nasdaq led with a 0.5% gain, moving the index onto positive ground for the week. The S&P 500 moved up 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average tacked on 0.3%. Options expirations boosted trading, sending volume about 200% higher on the Nasdaq and more than 400% higher on the NYSE compared with Thursday's activity.
Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR), which crashed 48% Wednesday, and Michael Kors (KORS) led the IBD 50, rising 5% apiece.
CommVault Systems (CVLT) popped 3% in opening trade. The data management and storage firm is just below its Sept. 14 high, but 8% above a 53.90 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Outside the IBD 50, Expedia (EXPE) gapped up to a 4% gain in heavy trade. Cantor Fitzgerald initiated coverage on the stock with a buy rating and a 64 price target. The report said the online travel broker was in the early stages of a turnaround, and further prospects for margin expansion. The move put the stock just below a 59.60 buy point in a six-week cup base.

Tibco Software (TIBX) vaulted 4% in huge trade. This year's corn harvest in the U.S. could be smaller than anticipated due to floods and foul weather during the planting season, new U.S. agriculture data out Thursday suggest, sending corn prices to a record high. But demand for corn and other grains isn't slowing at home or abroad, pressuring farmers to coax more from their land. That has investors…

The major indexes held on to strong gains and near session highs at midday, as a better-than-expected April jobs report continued to provide a boost. The Nasdaq was up 1.5%, while the NYSE and S&P 500 both traded 1.3% higher. Volume continued to track lower across the board. CF Industries (CF) jumped 7% in big turnover. Late Thursday, the fertilizer…

Stocks closed with modest gains on Friday, but well off the day's highs. When the closing bell rang, the Nasdaq, which had been up as much as 1.6%, had pared that gain to just 0.5%. The S&P 500 saw a 1.4% rise end at 0.4%. The NYSE composite ended up 0.3%, compared with its 1.5% intraday best. Volume declined on…

The major indexes traded nearly unchanged at midday Friday, despite a busy morning that included the latest GDP reading and a batch of corporate earnings results.The Nasdaq was up 0.1%. On the downside, the Dow and S&P 500 slipped 0.2% each and the NYSE composite edged down 0.1%. Volume fell 17% on the NYSE and was flat on the Nasdaq vs. the same period Thursday.CF Industries (CF) rose 4% in above-average volume. The fertilizer maker has rallied in step with other industry peers in the past few weeks and is now at a 52-week high. Fertilizers were among today's best-performing industry groups.VeriSign (VRSN) climbed 3% in triple its normal trade. The digital products maker topped third-quarter earnings views by a penny and matched revenue estimates. The stock fell hard early in the session but is now in new high ground.Priceline.com (PCLN) gained 3% in double its usual turnover. The discount travel services provider owns a highest-possible 99 Earnings Per Share Rating, with earnings growth of 30% or better in each of the past 12 quarters. Priceline's stock is also at a 52-week peak.

Stocks weakened to new session lows in late trade Thursday, but were still on pace for another week of gains.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 fell 0.3% each, while the NYSE composite slipped 0.2%. Turnover continued to track sharply lower on both exchanges ahead of the Christmas holiday.Agrium (AGU) rose 3% and neared a 86.88 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The stock sits just 3% off a 52-week high. In the past two quarters, the fertilizer maker's earnings grew 78% and 30%, respectively. But sales rose by high-single digits over the same period.Earlier, group mate C.F. Industries Holdings (CF) cleared a flat base. But it has a weak Earnings Per Share Rating of 53. Investors should focus on issues with EPS Ratings of 85 and up.On the downside, Crocs (CROX) dropped 5% in heavy trading. Earlier Thursday, the shoemaker announced the exit of its Chief Financial Officer Russell Hammer. The stock has made a big comeback since bottoming in November 2008. But it still needs to quadruple to match its October 2007 record high.

The major indexes continued to trade in a narrow range at midday Friday.The S&P 500 rose 0.2% and the NYSE composite added 0.1%. On the downside, the Nasdaq and Dow dipped 0.1% each. Volume rose 11% on the NYSE and fell 12% on the Nasdaq vs. the same period Thursday.Financials, metals, real estate and consumer stocks were among the day's best performing so far.Lululemon Athletica (LULU) rose 4% in more than twice its normal trade. The athletic apparel maker's stock is finding support at its 10-week moving average. The firm sports triple-digit earnings growth in the past three quarters.Puda Coal (PUDA) gained 5% in more than three times its average volume. The China-based provider of coal to steel makers saw its stock surge 14% on Wednesday after the company said it acquired two additional coal mines. The stock has surged 24% this week.Isilon Systems (ISLN) also advanced 5% in brisk turnover. The data storage provider's stock is bouncing off its 50-day moving average after finding support at that level on Thursday.
5:15 p.m. Update: Stocks jumped into the holiday week on a positive note, but volume was light.
The NYSE composite, Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 all took 1.4% gains. The Dow rose 1.3%. Volume fell across the board.
All but 5% of IBD's 197 industry groups posted advances. Consumer and commercial lenders and HMOs posted the day's biggest gains among industry groups.

Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) slumped 1% in after-hours trade after reporting fiscal Q4 EPS of $1.14. The 14% gain was in line with the company's Nov. 11 guidance and a penny above analysts' consensus estimate. Revenue slipped 8% to $30.8 billion, also in line with recent guidance and above consensus forecasts of $3.4 billion.

Tomorrow, prior to the market's open, the Commerce Department plans to release revised Q3 GDP data and Case-Shiller will unveil its September home price gauges. At 10 a.m., the Conference Board is set to deliver its November consumer confidence index. The Federal Open Market Committee is scheduled to release the minutes of its Nov. 4 meeting at 2 p.m.
Tuesday's earnings calendar includes Medtronic (MDT), before the market opens, and Blue Coat Systems (BCSI), China Finance Online (JRJC) and J. Crew (JCG) after hours.
Indexes Hold In Soft Trade

Stocks put in a session of low-volume gains Monday, as new optimism for Europe combined with some holdover bullishness after last week's better-than-expected U.S. jobs report. The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each added 0.2%. The major indexes backed off from headier gains, but still managed to score their highest closing prices…

Despite a better-than-expected report on weekly jobless claims, stocks ended narrowly mixed for a second straight session Thursday. Initial jobless claims slipped to 361,000 in the week ended Aug. 4, the Department of Labor reported. Views called for 367,000.

The Nasdaq rose 0.2% and the S&P 500 eked out a fractional gain. Both are still trading within the range of Tuesday's pop. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.1%. Volume fell for the second day in a row.
Even though the major averages didn't move much, some leading stocks did.

Tangoe (TNGO) gapped above its 50-day moving average and jumped 7% in nearly triple its average volume. The stock is in a cup-with-handle base with a 23.10 buy point. On a couple of down notes, price action has been wild rather than nice and tight. And the stock's handle corrected 19%, which is outside of the proper range of 8% to 12%.
Late Wednesday, the software maker delivered Q2 results above views and gave a rosy profit outlook for the current quarter.

CF Industries (CF) extended its win streak to five sessions. It added nearly 3% to a new high. It closed 5% past a 202.43 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. The stock has recently found its footing after initially struggling from a July 17 breakout.
Fertilizer makers have been strong recently due to severe drought conditions in the Midwest. The U.S. Department of Agriculture will release its crop report Friday.

OSI Systems (OSIS) bolted 11% in five-times average trade. The stock blew past a 68.10 buy point in a three-month flat base. OSI is a thin issue that trades just over 100,000 shares on average. Before the open, the medical gear maker trounced views with fiscal Q4 earnings that climbed 44% to 95 cents a share. That marked the second straight period of acceleration and its best performance in years. Sales, which also picked up for the second straight quarter, climbed 28% to $235.2 million.

On the downside, Copa Holdings (CPA) finished off its session low, but still down nearly 4% after gapping below its 50-day line. Late Wednesday, the Panamanian airline reported Q2 earnings of $1.32 a share, up 3% from a year ago. It missed views by 2 cents. Sales grew 21% to $515.8 million, also below views. The stock is in a double-bottom base with an 83.63 buy point. But Copa has a D Accumulation-Distribution Rating, which indicates that sellers have control.

SodaStream International (SODA) ended off Thursday's worst level, but still lost 1% in its third straight downside reversal. On Wednesday, the maker of home carbonation systems beat views with a 37% jump in Q2 earnings and a 49% gain in sales. SodaStream also raised its full-year growth forecast for profit and revenue. Yet SodaStream turned a 8% gain into a 1% loss. The stock cleared a 43.18 buy point from a cup-with-handle base Tuesday, but triggered the 8% sell rule the next day.

Stock futures showed healthy gains early Tuesday as Europe's markets rebounded, oil prices recovered from lows, and economic news was fair to positive.

Dow futures traded 75.5 points above fair market value, down from 100.5 points an hour earlier. Nasdaq 100 futures added to early gains and were up 29.1 points. S&P 500 futures moved up 11.7 points, even with hour-earlier levels.

The stock market today has its eye on Wednesday afternoon as the Federal Open Market Committee members head into their two-day powwow. Expectations are high for a policy shift when the group announces its decision on Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET.

Consumer prices were flat in November, the Labor Department reported. That was down from a 0.2% gain in October and in line with economist expectations. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.2% — equal to October's increase and meeting consensus projections.

Manufacturing activity in the New York region slowed at an improved rate in December, according to the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey. It showed a -4.6 performance vs. a -10.7 showing in November. That was better than the -7 reading expected by economists.
At 10 a.m., the National Association of Home Builders releases its builder confidence index. The Treasury Department reports long-term Treasury international capital flow for October at 4 p.m.

Oil prices took a modest bounce in early trade, lifting West Texas Intermediate less than 1% and Brent crude more than 1%, although still trading below $37 and $39 a barrel, respectively. That, and the late-day recovery of U.S. markets on Monday, fed a rebound across European markets. The leading indexes bounced up from 10-week lows, sending the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris up more than 2% near midday.

In stocks, miners and steel markets were rebounding, with issues like Vale (VALE) up 5% and Arcelor-Mittal (MT) ahead more than 4%. On the Dow, diversified operator 3M (MMM) — the old Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co., tanked more than 4% after lowering its 2015 earnings guidance. Chevron (CVX) topped the index in premarket trade with a 0.8% gain.
3M also notched the worst loss among S&P 500 stocks. F5 Networks (FFIV) took the second hardest hit, down a bit more than 2%.
Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) and Southwestern Energy (SWN) topped the list, all up better than 3%.

Flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators (LL) bolted 27% higher after news reports detailed a letter from Kase Capital Management Managing Partner Whitney Tilson, declaring that he had covered his short position against the stock.

Tilson had weighed in against the company following allegations that some of its flooring contained unsafe levels of formaldehyde. Tilson concluded that management probably did not know about the problem, according to Bloomberg, which means "the company was sloppy and naive, but not evil," Tilson wrote. The stock ended Monday down 80% since news of the investigation broke in February.

Leading stocks stuck to moderate moves in premarket action. Hawaiian (HA) topped the IBD 50 list, up slightly more than 1% in premarket trade. S&P 500 futures moved up 11.7 points, even with hour-earlier levels.The stock market today has its eye on Wednesday afternoon as the Federal Open Market Committee members head into their two-day powwow. Expectations are high for a policy shift when the group announces its decision on Wednesday at 2 p.m. ET.Consumer prices were flat in November, the Labor Department reported. That was down from a 0.2% gain in October and in line with economist expectations. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.2% — equal to October's increase and meeting consensus projections.Manufacturing activity in the New York region slowed at an improved rate in December, according to the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey. It showed a -4.6 performance vs. a -10.7 showing in November. That was better than the -7 reading expected by economists.At 10 a.m., the National Association of Home Builders releases its builder confidence index. The Treasury Department reports long-term Treasury international capital flow for October at 4 p.m.Oil prices took a modest bounce in early trade, lifting West Texas Intermediate less than 1% and Brent crude more than 1%, although still trading below $37 and $39 a barrel, respectively. That, and the late-day recovery of U.S. markets on Monday, fed a rebound across European markets. The leading indexes bounced up from 10-week lows, sending the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris up more than 2% near midday.In stocks, miners and steel markets were rebounding, with issues like Vale (VALE) up 5% and Arcelor-Mittal (MT) ahead more than 4%. On the Dow, diversified operator 3M (MMM) — the old Minnesota Mining & Manufacturing Co., tanked more than 4% after lowering its 2015 earnings guidance. Chevron (CVX) topped the index in premarket trade with a 0.8% gain.3M also notched the worst loss among S&P 500 stocks. F5 Networks (FFIV) took the second hardest hit, down a bit more than 2%.Chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA), Newell Rubbermaid (NWL) and Southwestern Energy (SWN) topped the list, all up better than 3%.Flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators (LL) bolted 27% higher after news reports detailed a letter from Kase Capital Management Managing Partner Whitney Tilson, declaring that he had covered his short position against the stock.Tilson had weighed in against the company following allegations that some of its flooring contained unsafe levels of formaldehyde. Tilson concluded that management probably did not know about the problem, according to Bloomberg, which means "the company was sloppy and naive, but not evil," Tilson wrote. The stock ended Monday down 80% since news of the investigation broke in February.Leading stocks stuck to moderate moves in premarket action. Hawaiian (HA) topped the IBD 50 list, up slightly more than 1% in premarket trade. Dave & Buster's (PLAY) staked out the low end with a 2% loss.

Agrium (AGU) stock rose on its earnings report Friday, as rivals' shares gained too. But Agrium and other fertilizer producers and farm suppliers could see curtailed demand if the drought continues and farmers plant fewer crops. The drought has already burned corn and soybean crops in the Midwest, driving prices up. There could be a slight reduction in fertilizer purchases…

Stocks advanced for a second straight session Monday, but gave up some gains in the session's final minutes. The Nasdaq added 0.7% after being up 1.1% intraday and briefly poking above 3000. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 tacked on 0.2%. All three indexes closed at their best levels since early May. Volume decreased on both main exchanges…
Stocks turned up in early-afternoon trading Tuesday as investors mulled rising Spanish bond yields and mixed U.S. economic data.
The Nasdaq rose 0.5%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.2% in a seesaw session. Volume was higher on the Nasdaq and up slightly on the NYSE compared with the same time Monday.

Home prices rose 1.3% in April vs. March, the first monthly increase since September, according to the Case-Shiller home price indexes. Compared with a year ago, prices were down a less-than-expected 1.9%.
However, the Conference Board's consumer confidence index fell 2.4 points in June to 62, less than the expected 63.5.
Meanwhile, Spain's short-term borrowing costs almost tripled at an auction Tuesday ahead of a two-day European Union summit meeting later this week aimed at stemming the region's financial crisis.
Agriculture, homebuilder and education stocks led the gains.

Fertilizer maker CF Industries (CF), an IBD 50 stock, climbed more than 3% after rising 3% and 1.5% in the prior two sessions. CF was one of several fertilizer stocks upgraded Monday by brokerage Dahlman Rose. The stock is climbing the right side of a base.

Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) jumped more than 5%, bolting above its 50-day line in strong trade. Lennar is expected to report early Wednesday that profit for the latest quarter surged 143% from a year ago to 17 cents a share.
Luxury homebuilder Toll Brothers (TOL) also retook its 50-day line after a 5% gain. New-home sales jumped 7.6% in May to a two-year high, government data showed Monday.

Meanwhile, for-profit education stock Apollo Group (APOL) soared more than 8% in huge volume after fiscal third-quarter profit beat forecasts and the company raised its full-year earnings guidance. But the stock is still well below its 200-day moving average and 39% below a 52-week peak.
Strayer Education (STRA) added 5% and DeVry (DV) gained more than 4%.

Elsewhere, Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. (NWS) jumped more than 6% in heavy volume, breaking above a 21.04 buy point from a flat base. The company said Tuesday that it may split its publishing and entertainment divisions. The company is suffering from a phone-hacking scandal involving its now-closed News of the World tabloid newspaper.

On the downside, Coinstar (CSTR) lost more than 1% in heavy trade after the operator of Redbox DVD rental kiosks said its 2012 earnings will suffer because of its purchase of NCR Corp.'s (NCR) Blockbuster video kiosks. Coinstar assumed certain liabilities as part of the $100 million purchase.

Coinstar is below a 69.84 entry in a cup base and remains above its 50-day moving average. It may be forming a handle. Sociedad Quimica y Minera de Chile (SQM) showed its mettle in Thursday's rocky session: It faced a barrage of potentially devastating factors, yet stood tall. The broad market sell-off could easily have been the stock's undoing. Certainly, before the afternoon bounce, many other stocks suffered badly. Santiago, Chile-based Sociedad Quimica y Minera faced another problem: Grains prices were diving, part…

Stocks stumbled to new session lows in late trading Friday and were on pace to end a volatile week on a mixed note. The Nasdaq dropped 1.7%, the S&P 500 1.5%, the Dow Jones industrial average 1.3%. Alcoa (AA) lost 3% and hit a two-year low. Bank of America (BAC) and American Express (AXP) were also hard-hit. Volume was tracking…
Stocks extended their gains Wednesday afternoon after the Federal Reserve pledged to keep interest rates near zero until the jobless rate falls to 6.5% from the current 7.7%.

The S&P 500 rose 0.6%, the Dow Jones industrial average 0.4% and the Nasdaq 0.2%, building on smaller gains earlier. Volume was down 12% on the Nasdaq and 2% on the NYSE, compared with the same time Tuesday.
The central bank also said it would expand its purchases of Treasury bonds to keep interest rates low and stimulate the sluggish economy.
Lululemon Athletica (LULU), a Canada-based retailer of high-end yoga apparel, was up 1% in double its average daily volume as it works on a base-on-base pattern.
The stock has risen for three straight weeks, including an upside reversal last week. But it's a late-stage base, which is more prone to failure than first- or second-stage patterns.
Financial Engines (FNGN), a thinly traded portfolio manager, is rising 3% in strong volume as it lifts off its 10-week line.
The company's earnings have risen 43%, 22% and 62% in the past three quarters, following a couple quarters of declines. Revenue rose 29%, 26%, 36% in those same reports.

Akamai Technologies (AKAM), which helps companies speed the delivery of content over the Internet, rose 2% to a 52-week high. It's also barely pushing past its 40.42 buy point from a 10-week consolidation.
The stock soared above its 50-day line Dec. 6 after announcing an alliance with AT&T (T) to provide content delivery services.
On the downside, fertilizer maker CF Industries (CF) lost 2% in fast trade, sinking below a 215.10 handle buy point. It had cleared the entry Tuesday in light trade.

Also, drug maker Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) dipped 1%, reversing lower after hitting a new high and clearing a 90.10 flat-base buy point.Stocks extended their gains Wednesday afternoon after the Federal Reserve pledged to keep interest rates near zero until the jobless rate falls to 6.5% from the current 7.7%.The S&P 500 rose 0.6%, the Dow Jones industrial average 0.4% and the Nasdaq 0.2%, building on smaller gains earlier. Stocks opened mixed Wednesday as earnings results drove the bulk of early market activity.
The Nasdaq rose 0.2%. The S&P 500 wrestled to hold a fractional gain. The Dow Jones industrial average lagged, down 0.2%.
Volume was mixed in the stock market today, up 10% on the Nasdaq and down 4% on the NYSE.

In stocks, Delta Air Lines (DAL) climbed more than 2% after its Q2 earnings met estimates and revenue narrowly beat views. The stock is seven weeks into a consolidation, working to form a bottom and retake its 50-day moving average.

Broadcom (BRCM) muscled up 4% in powerful trade. The communications-chip company reported late Tuesday its Q2 EPS slipped less than expected, although revenue dipped 2%, more than projected. But margins were wider than anticipated, Q3 revenue guidance was above expectations and management announced it would trim 2,500 jobs as it exits its baseband chip business.

On the downside, Xilinx (XLNX) collapsed 18% after missing its fiscal Q1 revenue forecasts late Tuesday and paring Q2 revenue guidance below views. Both Bank of America and BMO Capital downgraded the stock early Wednesday.

Among leaders, 3-in-5 of the IBD 50 listed stocks advanced at the start of trade. Losses were moderate, with only Ubiquiti Networks (UBNT), Ambarella (AMBA) and Arris Group (ARRS) slipping more than 1%.

On the upside, Biogen Idec (BIIB) popped 12% after blowing past second-quarter sales and earnings forecasts and raising full-year EPS and revenue guidance to well above expectations. The stock broke out past a 333.07 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Lithia Motors (LAD) jumped 5% on positive second-quarter results.
